video.title: Full Stack Web App using Vue.js & Express.js: Part 1 - Intro
video.description:
Welcome to part 1 of a new series where I will create a full stack web application using Vue.js and Express.js

🎥Video created by Cody Seibert. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsrVDPJBYeXItETFHG0qzyw

00:00 Project description
6:35 Git Setup
17:47 Backend setup
36:40 Register page setup

GitHub repo: https://github.com/codyseibert/tab-tracker

Follow Cody on Twitter: https://twitter.com/CodyLSeibert

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.com

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.com

topLevelComment.author: Fanglu Lim
topLevelComment.text:
Can someone help with this? 
ESLint: 7.32.0

You are linting "node_modules/ipaddr.js", but all of the files matching the glob pattern "node_modules/ipaddr.js" are ignored.

If you don't want to lint these files, remove the pattern "node_modules/ipaddr.js" from the list of arguments passed to ESLint.

If you do want to lint these files, try the following solutions:

* Check your .eslintignore file, or the eslintIgnore property in package.json, to ensure that the files are not configured to be ignored.
* Explicitly list the files from this glob that you'd like to lint on the command-line, rather than providing a glob as an argument.

topLevelComment.author: ToFu
topLevelComment.text:
54:00 If your Client gets a 404 error when hitting on Register button in (check F12), take a look at the POST URL. It needs to go to port 8081, but in my case it led to 8080 (POST http://localhost:8080/register) and it seemed like it overrode my settings.

The problem was that I misspelled BaseURL in Api.js; if you spell it BaseUrl, the program still works without errors but doesn't take the settings.

topLevelComment.author: Drew Walsh
topLevelComment.text:
ESlint is great if you spend the time to set it up. Linting can save a ton of time if you spend a little time reading the docs and setting it up to work best for you. If you don't care to do that completely fair to remove it rather then fight with strict styling rules that don't work with your style.

 I'm not a fan line of command line linting, mine lints through VSCode and I have a .eslintrc in my home folder (Ubuntu) I use for everything. If I ever need different linting rules I just copy it to my project folder and change whatever I need to change and it'll use that one instead. I find it really handy, especially in combination with Prettier and setup to auto format on save to comply with my ESlint rules. 

Also thanks for the great tutorial!

topLevelComment.author: Waymoot
topLevelComment.text:
In Windows I had a lot of trouble getting body-parser to work.
After many hours of trying different things it boiled down to the addons (postman for chrome) to NOT sending the application/json content-type even though I had selected "json" as the payload to send.
Not until I installed filddler proxy I saw that the content type was wrong.
So make sure that you really are sending application/json as the Content-type to get this to work.
I switched to Rested addon for Firefox where I could set the headers manually and now it works fine.

topLevelComment.author: BJJ BARN
topLevelComment.text:
If you are having problems around 22:00 mins (WINDOWS USERS) make sure you follow the steps to install ES LINT then your package.json file should look like this:

{
  "name": "server",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "nodemon --watch src --exec npm run server",
    "server": "node src/app.js",
    "lint": "eslint **/*.js"
  },
  "keywords": [],
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC"
}


Worked for me after a lot of trial -> HOPE IT HELPS!

Make sure nodemon is installed globally -> npm install -g nodemon

topLevelComment.author: TJ Walker
topLevelComment.text: 20:22 - If I'm not mistaken, part of the benefit of npm scripts is that it adds locally installed (`npm install` without `--global`) executables (node_modules/.bin/) to the PATH environment variable. So, these executables that, if run directly off the command line would need a fully qualified path, don't need that when run from a script within `packag.json` via `npm run x`. That's to say, instead of `./node_modules/nodemon/bin/nodemon.js ...` and `./node_module/.bin/eslint ...` you could just do `nodemon ...` and `eslint ...` respectively.

replies.author: Scarlet Letters Productions
replies.text:
This bit in the package.json was shorthand for saying "npm run lint src/app.js" and "node src/app.js"
it is effectively saying "nodemon have npm run the linter over our src/app.js and then have node run src/app.js"
node is the command used to run NodeJS files
